clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of a Comics-based Intervention to Promote Positive Body Image Among Adolescents in India
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomised Control Trial Evaluating a Comics-based Intervention to Promote Positive Body Image Among Adolescents in India

lead_sponsor.agency: University of the West of England

clinical_study.source: University of the West of England

brief_summary.textblock:
Body image is one of the leading concerns for young. Such concerns can have serious health consequences, including unhealthy weight control and exercise behaviours, depression and self-harm, low self-esteem, substance abuse. Emerging approaches for improving body image are effective among adolescent girls and boys in the school setting. However, the vast majority of trials in this area are conducted in high-income westernised countries, despite body image concerns increasingly being recognised as a global concern. As such, it is important to develop and disseminate interventions to promote positive body image among adolescents in in low-to-middle income countries, too.
One country where body image concerns are becoming an increasing issue is India. The investigators recently finished developing and evaluating a body image programme, Dove Confident Me, among adolescents in New Delhi, India. The investigators found immediate and 3-month follow-up improvements in body image, disordered eating, self-esteem, and other related outcomes. Whilst these findings offer an effective body image programme for school students in urban areas of India, this may not be feasible for schools in more rural areas in India.
The aim of the present study is therefore to conduct an acceptability study, followed by a pilot randomised controlled trial, of a comics-based body image programme among adolescents in a rural area of India (Rajasthan), in order to understand its acceptability, feasibility, and preliminary efficacy. This comics-based programme will be based on Dove Confident Me, which was found to be effective among adolescents in Delhi, India.
To assess the acceptability of the comic-book-based programme, interviews will be conducted with students in one school to explore their thoughts on the comic books e.g., What do they like? Could they identify with the characters? What were the key messages? Focus groups will also be conducted with teachers to understand their thoughts on the comic-book-based programme, e.g., Do they think the content is appropriate for their students? How could the key messages be improved? Is the Teacher Guide easy to understand? Investigators will gather in-depth feedback from students and teachers, and this will be used to optimise the programme prior to a randomised controlled trial (RCT).
Next, to assess the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of the comic-book-based programme, an RCT will allow comparisons of the body image and well-being of students who take part in the programme to students who do not take part in any programme (classes as usual). To undertake the RCT, the investigators will recruit students and teachers from six schools in a rural area of India (Rajasthan). Students will complete questionnaire assessments of body image and well-being before and after the 5-week programme period, and again 10-12 weeks later to assess longer-term benefits.

detailed_description.textblock:
Background:
Body image is a significant and prevalent concern for adolescents in high-income countries such as the UK, the USA, and Australia. For example, a study of 1,600 girls in the UK found that four in ten 11-16 year old girls are unhappy with the way they look. Similarly, a nationally representative survey of nearly 22,000 young people in Australia found that 3 in 10 adolescent boys and girls are very concerned about their body image, and body image was voted among the top three life concerns. The high prevalence of body image concerns among adolescent boys and girls is worrisome, given their serious negative physical and psychological health consequences. For example, body dissatisfaction is associated with engagement in unhealthy weight loss behaviours and the onset of eating disorders, depression and self-harm, substance use, and lower levels of academic engagement.
There is increasing recognition that body image is a global issue, as opposed to one relegated to privileged adolescents in high-income Westernised countries. For example, in India, 57% of adolescents aged 15-19 years report being concerned with their appearance. Further, adolescent girls across different regions of India have expressed concerns in relation to their weight and report dieting behaviours. Skin colour has also been indicated as an additional source of appearance concern among young people in India. A large-scale study among Asian, African, and South American countries, found that 19% of Indian undergraduate students had used a skin lightening product in the previous 12 months, strongly suggesting dissatisfaction with their natural skin tone, which may be pertinent to younger groups.
Collectively, these findings indicate the importance of developing and disseminating interventions to promote positive body image among adolescents in India. The investigators recently finished developing and evaluating a school-based body image programme, Dove Confident Me, among adolescents in New Delhi, India. Immediate and 3-month follow-up improvements were found in body image, disordered eating, self-esteem, and other related outcomes. Whilst these findings offer an effective body image programme for school students in urban areas of India, this may not be feasible for schools in more rural areas in India; where they do not have electricity or computers.
The aim of the present study is therefore to conduct an acceptability study followed by a pilot randomised controlled trial of a comics-based body image programme among adolescents in a rural area of India (Rajasthan), in order to understand its acceptability, feasibility, and preliminary efficacy. This comic-book-based programme will be based on Dove Confident Me, which was found to be effective among adolescents in Delhi, India.
Design:
First, an acceptability study will be conducted to explore the target group's opinions of the comic books. Interviews will be conducted with 24 students across years 6-8 in one government school. They will be asked questions such as: What do they like about the comic books? Could they identify with the characters in the stories? What did they think were the key messages? Focus groups will also be conducted with 9 teachers who teach across years 6-8 of the school to understand their thoughts on the comic-book-based programme. They will be asked questions such as: Do they think the content is appropriate for their students? How could the key messages be improved? Is the Teacher Guide easy to understand? Investigators will gather in-depth feedback from students and teachers, and this will be used to optimise the programme prior to conducting a cluster randomised controlled trial (RCT).
Next, a cluster RCT will be conducted, whereby at least 8 schools (aiming for 2,400 students across both conditions) will be randomly allocated to receive the comic-book-based body image intervention or classes-as-usual (control). Students will be assessed on body image and related outcomes at baseline, post-intervention and 10-12 weeks follow-up, under standardised conditions.
Participants & recruitment:
For the acceptability study, one co-educational government school in Rajasthan will be invited to take part. 24 students across years 6-8 (50% male) will be randomly selected by the headmaster to participate in the interviews, if the students so wish to. Focus groups will also be conducted with 9 teachers who teach across years 6-8 of the school. The head master will also select these teachers, and aim to ensure variability in terms of age, gender, and length of time teaching.
Regarding the RCT, at least eight co-educational government schools in Rajasthan will be invited to take part. All students in classes 6-8 (equivalent of UK years 7-9; students aged 11-14) in each school will be invited to take part. The total number of schools will depend on the number of students across the year groups. However, the aim will be to recruit 1,200 students for each condition, with 50% males. This will allow us to detect a small effect.
For both studies (acceptability and RCT), after expressing their initial interest, each school will receive detailed information regarding the aims, objective and requirements of the study to help them decide if they would like to take part in this research project. Depending on the school, either the head teacher will provide active informed consent, or parents will consent. Students will also be required to provide their consent before taking part. All students will have the opportunity to opt out of the study, or withdraw from the study at any time, irrespective of head teacher consent.
Intervention:
AdhaFULL AdhaFULL is a comic-book series co-created by BBC Media Action and UNICEF, which follows the journey of 3 adolescents as they solve cases related to important issues (e.g., under-age marriage, nutrition, gender-stereotypes, peer pressure etc). The comics aim to raise awareness and encourage adolescents to take action against these issues. There are 6 different comics based on AdhaFULL, which target issues relating to gender stereotypes and appearance concerns amongst adolescents in rural India. Specifically, they focus on gender prejudice (Comic 1), societal appearance ideals (Comic 2), media literacy (Comic 3), appearance comparisons (Comic 4), appearance-related conversations and teasing (Comic 5), and promoting 'body activism' (Comic 6). At the end of each comic, the teacher will facilitate one or two activities with the students based on the comic.
Procedure:
Investigators from the Centre for Appearance Research (CAR) based at the University of the West of England will be leading the study remotely from Bristol, UK. CAR researchers will be responsible for designing the study, analysing the data, and writing up the manuscript. They will also be working with the Dove Self-Esteem Project, UNICEF, and BBC Media Action to design the comics. The investigators will work with an Indian research agency, who will be 'on the ground' collecting the data (as travel from the UK is currently forbidden due to the COVID-19 pandemic).
1. Acceptability Study As described above, both students and teacher will participate in interviews and focus group to provide their thoughts and opinions on the comic books (in addition to the Teacher Guide among teachers). Permission to audio record the focus groups and interviews will be sought from participants prior to commencing the discussions.
2. RCT Independent randomisation by a blinded researcher external to the project will be used to assign schools to each condition. This will be done using freely available computer software. The teachers of years 6-8 will be trained by two researchers from CAR and/or collaborators.
A questionnaire comprising the self-report measures described below will be used to assess the impact of the intervention on students' body image and associated risk factors. After obtaining consent from the school head teachers, and the students, these measures will be administered in the classroom to the 11-14-year-old students at pre-intervention (1-2 weeks before intervention delivery), immediately after intervention delivery (within 1 week of the final session), and again at 10-12 weeks follow-up. The questionnaire will take students no more than 20-25 minutes to complete. Students will complete questionnaires under standardised conditions supervised by their teachers and trained research staff. Blinding of students, teachers, and researchers is not possible due to the nature of the intervention. However, risk of bias from teachers and researchers is minimised due to anonymous self-report assessments. Risk of contagion is also minimised by randomising at the school level. This project has ethical approval from the University of the West of England's Faculty Research Ethics Committee.
In order to assess the fidelity of the intervention manuals, all sessions will be audio-recorded as well as observed by a researcher and rated based on adherence to lesson plans. The teachers will be asked to complete a brief form after each lesson stating which activities were completed.

study_design_info.masking_description: Masking not possible for participants within design, but outcome assessors will not know what condition participants are assigned to.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in body esteem over time: Body Esteem Scale for adolescents & adults (Mendelson, Mendelson & White, 2001).
primary_outcome.description: Assessment of body esteem using Body Esteem Scale for adolescents & adults,18 items, 5-point Likert-type scale. Once the appropriate items are reverse coded, scores on all items are averaged; with lower scores indicating lower body esteem.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in eating pathology over time: Eating Disorder Examination Questionnaire (Fairburn & Beglin, 2008)
secondary_outcome.description: Assessment of eating disorder pathology using Eating Disorder Examination Questionnaire, 28 items, 7-point Likert-type scale. Scores on all items are averaged; with higher scores indicating greater eating pathology

secondary_outcome.measure: Internalisation of appearance ideals: The Sociocultural Attitudes Towards Appearance scale-3 (SATAQ-3): General Subscale (Thompson, Van Den Berg, Roehrig, Guarda, & Heinberg, 2004).
secondary_outcome.description: Assessment of internalisation of appearance ideals using The Sociocultural Attitudes Towards Appearance scale-3 (SATAQ-3): General Subscale, 9 items, mean score range 1-5. Scores are averaged, with higher scores indicating higher internalisation

secondary_outcome.measure: Life engagement Scale (Atkinson & Diedrichs, Manuscript in Preparation)
secondary_outcome.description: Purpose-built measure assessing the extent that worries or feeling bad about the way you look has stopped you, or are likely to stop you, from engaging in life activities (e.g., going to a social event, doing physical activity, giving an opinion, going to school), 10 items, mean score range 1-4. Scores on all items are averaged; with higher scores indicating greater avoidance of activities due to appearance concerns.

secondary_outcome.measure: Positive and Negative Affect: The Positive and Negative Affect Scale (Crawford & Henry, 2004)
secondary_outcome.description: Positive and Negative affect schedule- short form, 10 items, mean score range 1-5. Scores on the five items for the Positive Affect and Negative Affect subscales are averaged; with higher scores indicating greater negative affect and positive affect.
Assessment of self-esteem using the Short-Form Rosenberg Self-Esteem scale, 10 items, mean score range 1-5. Scores are averaged, with higher scores indicating greater self-esteem

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Hindi speaking and literate 11-14 year old students at participating schools
Exclusion Criteria:
- History of an eating disorder
- Non-Hindi speaking
